intro: Dryadodaphne celastroides, commonly known as the ghost flower, is a striking plant native to South Africa. It is a member of the family Euphorbiaceae and is characterized by its unique, lantern-like inflorescence that appears ghostly in the dark. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers surrounded by colorful bracts, which are often mistaken for petals. It thrives in well-drained soils and requires full sun to partial shade for optimal growth. Due to its ornamental value and rarity, it is often cultivated in gardens and botanical collections.
